ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Developed a deep understanding of Donne and his poetry.
I gained a broad knowledge of the poems and sermons of John Donne.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great selection of readings on John Donne!

Professor Nicholson is a GEM. She can (and will) make absolutely any topic an interesting and engaging one, and when dealing with the same author for an entire term, that is a very underrated skill to have. Every week brought with it new and interesting discussions. I honestly didn't think there could be that much to discuss concerning one guy, but there absolutely was. Only weakness would be if you aren't invested enough in Donne himself.

Overall - Prof. Nicholson is an excellent, extremely knowledgeable instructor, especially with a good eye for providing insightful written feedback and for her presence in the classroom. I think there were some structural problems with the course; I did not feel prepared for the final paper going into it. 

At the level of the syllabus, I think, given that we were mostly doing close readings, that there should be less but more focused readings. We probably only talked about less than half of the ~10 assigned poems for any given week, often through a reading that was non-evident and I was discovering in class in really time, so preparing for class felt kind of ad-hoc - I felt about as prepared for the classes where I had done all the readings closely as those when I skimmed the poems. I feel like the syllabus could be balanced by reducing the number of poems down to, like, 4-5 poems a week, which the students are required to *closely* close read, maybe aided by a weekly assignment. I know this is supposed to be an upper level course, but regardless of students' experience with poetry it's just not possible to treat 10-11 poems with any reasonable care within an hour and fifty minutes. It'd also be much easier to group poems thematically this way. To counterbalance the reduction in poems, I think there should be much more secondary critical literature, like double the amount, both on Donne, but also on Early modern poetics in general, so that students can come away with more history of literature knowledge that they can use to contextualize their other studies. We didn't talk very much about the secondary critical literature or the biographies - I wish we had - as they would have given more of a framework / through line / momentum of the course.

 There were something like 5 people talking consistently in a class of 15. There were a number of people who never talked the entire semester except for the one or two times we went around the room and, e.g. everyone shared what they were working on for the final project. I think that a lot of the issues with discussion in the course had nothing to do with the syllabus, the readings, or Prof. Nicholson - the class was genuinely not very engaged, just from the get go, and I'm really sorry for that - Prof. Nicholson was working very hard during discussion to engage a class that was just fundamentally difficult to engage. I think a lot of people in the class were there because of the Renaissance requirement/senior seminar and not there for an original interest in Donne. (admittedly, sort of myself included, initially - I came across a number of poems I really loved, though, and I'm ultimately quite glad I took this course)

I think one way to improve the engagement in the course would be to set higher expectations for the reading responses. In the first class, Prof. Nicholson made it clear that they were fairly low stakes, that they would just be graded for completion, and that we could put just a short question or something - although I often didn't do this, I somewhat wish there was a requirement to do like, at least 300 words and to advance an argument about the poems for that week. Possibly some group discussions/presentations of poems/texts would be helpful?

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend! I didn't know anything about John Donne going in the course, but learned a ton.

I would recommend this class to English majors looking for any of the requirements this class fills, or to anyone interested in Donne generally. Prof. Nicholson makes the class worth taking, and it's a great way to explore how a writer's life impacts the work they produce throughout their life.

I have mixed feelings - I came across some poems in this class that were truly remarkable, and will stick with me for a long time, but I would not recommend this course to another student unless it receives a significant syllabus / structural overhaul.
